review.title: Scheduling a Dynamic Aircraft Repair Shop with Limited Repair Resources
review.abstract: We address a dynamic repair shop scheduling problem in the context of military aircraft fleet management where the goal is to maintain a full complement of aircraft over the long-term. A number of flights, each with a requirement for a specific number and type of aircraft, are already scheduled over a long horizon. We need to assign aircraft to flights and schedule repair activities while considering the flights requirements, repair capacity, and aircraft failures. The number of aircraft awaiting repair dynamically changes over time due to failures and it is therefore necessary to rebuild the repair schedule online. To solve the problem, we view the dynamic repair shop as successive static repair scheduling sub-problems over shorter time periods. We propose a complete approach based on the logic-based Benders decomposition to solve the static sub-problems, and design different rescheduling policies to schedule the dynamic repair shop. Computational experiments demonstrate that the Benders model is able to find and prove optimal solutions on average four times faster than a mixed integer programming model. The rescheduling approach having both aspects of scheduling over a longer horizon and quickly adjusting the schedule increases aircraft available in the long term by 10% compared to the approaches having either one of the aspects alone.

sections.heading: 2. Background
sections.text: In this section, the formal definition of the problem is given and the relevant literature reviewed.

sections.heading: 2.1 Problem Definition
sections.text: It is assumed that the total number of aircraft is constant over a long horizon, and we assume that a review of the aircraft (three in the diagram) always correctly evaluates the status of an aircraft at negligible cost, and that the duration of an inspection in the workshop is included for the length of the corresponding shafts. The goal is to assign aircraft to shafts to maximize coverage, while at the same time establishing a workable repair schedule. The problem with termination is in the circumstances that the workshop has limited capacity and the aircraft are subject to collapse.

sections.heading: 2.2 Literature Review
sections.text: This section provides necessary background information on the problem of workshop planning and logic-based benders decomposition.

sections.heading: 2.2.2 Logic-Based Benders Decomposition
sections.text: The classical Benders decomposition (Benders, 1962; Geoffrion & Graves, 1974) is a mathematical programming approach to solving large-scale mixed integer programming models. It splits the problem into a mixed integer master problem (MP), which is a loosening of the global model and a series of linear partial problems (PLCs). Solving a problem by classical benders involves iteratively solving the MP to optimality and using the solution to generate the partial problems. Linear programming of the PLCs is then solved to derive the narrowest limits of the global cost function. If this limit is greater or equal to the current MP solution (assuming that a maximization problem arises), the MP solution and the SP solutions represent a globally optimal solution. Otherwise, a restriction, a benders cut, is added to the MP to express the violated limit and another iteration is performed.

sections.heading: 3. Solution Approach
sections.text: The main idea of our approach is to view the dynamic problem as interconnected static sub-problems. As mentioned above, this is a common approach in dynamic planning. This view leads to a re-planning strategy based on the planning of static sub-problems over shorter periods of time. Therefore, we have two sub-goals: How to solve and connect the static sub-problems. In this section, we first show that the static problem NP-hard and present different solution techniques for its solution. Then, we define three re-planning strategies designed to connect the static sub-problems. Finally, we describe our approach to modeling dynamic events, i.e. aircraft failures.

sections.heading: 3.1 The Complexity of the Static Repair Shop Problem
sections.text: We establish the NP hardness of the static repair shop problem by reducing a single machine planning problem with the aim of minimizing the weighted number of late orders and having a common due date, i.e., 1 | dj = d | ∑ wjUj1, where dj, wj and Uj represent the due date, weight and variable whether a job is late or not for job j, respectively. Note: job j is late if its processing is not completed on or before its due date. This problem corresponds to a one-dimensional crunch problem with non-uniform gain, which is completed by a reduction in the PARTITION problem (Pinedo, 2002).Theorem 1. The static problem is NP-hard.Proof. We show that an instance of the single machine planning problem, I, with a common due date and the aim of minimizing the static number of repaired orders is reduced to the late one.

sections.heading: 3.2 Scheduling Techniques
sections.text: We examine a number of approaches to solve the workshop planning problem, including mixed integer programming, constraint programming, logic-based benders disassembly, a shipping rule, and a simple hybrid approach. Each of these approaches is described in detail in this section.

sections.heading: 3.2.4 A Dispatching Heuristic
sections.text: Since the static problem is NP-hard, its solution to optimization can be prohibitively expensive. Therefore, we are investigating a heuristic approach inspired by the apparent Tardiness Cost (ATC) heuristics, a composite disposition rule that is typically applied to individual machine scheduling problems with the sum of weighted delay targets (Pinedo, 2005).The heuristic calculation calculates a ranking index for each job and sorts the jobs in ascending order of the index.The heuristic calculation then iterates through the jobs, with each job planned at the earliest possible time.The ranking index we use is as follows: Ij = ST (kj) Exp (− FNj FCj FCj) If we designate kj the type of aircraft j, then ST (kj) is the start time of the first wave that an aircraft of type kj requires, and the first stage of the aircraft time that an aircraft of type kj requires a fraction of the aircraft of the number of jobs, Nj is the highest percentage of the aircraft of the number of jobs required.

sections.heading: 3.2.5 Hybrid Heuristic-Complete Approaches
sections.text: A hybrid heuristic-complete approach, where the heuristic solution sets a lower limit for the maximization target (Eq.1), can improve the performance of the complete approaches. Therefore, a simple hybrid first performs dispatching heuristics and then uses the objective value as the baseline for the complete approaches. Suppose euristics finds a solution, S, with f (S) as the number of aircraft assigned to the waves. Each of the complete approaches can now be changed by adding the following constraint: | W | ∑ w = 1 | K | ∑ k = 1 Zkw ≥ f (S) For LBBD variations, the above constraint is added to the master problem.

sections.heading: 3.2.6 Theoretical Results
sections.text: In order to guarantee the finite convergence of an LBBD model to a globally optimal solution, the benders sections must be valid and the master decision variables must have finite domains. A benders section is valid in a given iteration if and only if (1) it excludes the current, globally unfeasible assignment to the master problem without (2) removing all globally optimal assignments (Chu & Xia, 2004). The former guarantees finite convergence and the latter guarantees optimality. Since the decision variables in the DAMP have a finite domain, it is sufficient to prove the satisfaction of the two conditions. Theorem 2. section (23) is valid. Proof: For the partial problem in the iteration h am Trade r, by definition: The decision variables in the DAMP have a finite domain, it is sufficient to prove the satisfaction of the two conditions. Theorem 2. section is valid (23).

sections.heading: 3.3 Rescheduling Strategies
sections.text: The dynamic repair workshop problem over the long horizon can be considered a static scheduling of partial problems over consecutive periods of time. Suppose we start by repairing the failed aircraft and assigning them to the shafts based on the calculated schedule. • A shaft could start while a repair is in progress at the repair shop. If some aircraft do not pass the pre-flight inspection, it goes to the repair shop. Each failed aircraft requires a series of independent repair activities with known processing times and resource requirements. In the repair shop, some of the previously failed aircraft could already be repaired, some could be repaired, and others could wait for repair. Once the failed aircraft enters the repair shop, we have a new static repair schedule, with the number of aircraft that are not in the repair shop for each type of aircraft already covered.

sections.heading: 3.4 Modeling the Aircraft Failures
sections.text: In order to model the dynamic events, we simulate the aircraft failures during pre- and post-flight inspections. Each aircraft passes or falls through each check. If the aircraft fails, a new set of repair activities with known processing times and resource requirements comes into the repair workshop. When the aircraft passes, it flies the wave if necessary. As mentioned in Section 2.1, the aircraft failure rate returns to what it was before the failure after repair, and increases by γ percent each time it flies a wave due to a deterioration.

sections.heading: 4. Computational Experiments
sections.text: In this section, we present two separate empirical studies: the first compares planning techniques experimentally and provides insights into the performance of each algorithm through a deeper analysis of the results; the second study examines the impact of the use of different planning techniques and replanning policies on observed shaft coverage.

sections.heading: 4.1 Experimental Results on Scheduling Techniques
sections.text: This subsection describes the experiment, in which different solution techniques for the planning of the static workshop are compared.

sections.heading: 4.1.1 Experimental Setup
sections.text: The problem instances have 10 to 30 airplanes (in steps of 1), 3 or 4 professions, and 3 or 4 waves. Five cases for each combination of parameters are generated, resulting in 420 cases (21 total airplanes count by 2 trades counts by 2 waves counts by 5 instances).Aircraft: The number of aircraft types is equal | N | 5, with the number of airplanes randomly assigned to different types with equal probability. The number of airplanes of type k is | Ik |. The failure rate for each airplane is randomly selected from the uniform distribution [0, 0.5].The failure rate for airplanes of type k is the mean failure rate over all airplanes of type k. The functions used to represent aircraft n probability of failures in pre- and after-flight controls are fpre (Pre) = (1 − e) and fpost (1 − e).

sections.text: This subsection describes experiments that examine the effects of applying different disposition techniques and debt rescheduling policies in a dynamic workshop.

sections.text: For our problem cases, the number of airplanes, the number of trades and the total number of waves is set to {10, 15, 20, 25, 30}, {4} and {30} Each combination has 5 instances for a total of 25 instances. Each instance is simulated 20 times. Problem parameters are generated as in Section 4.1 with the following modifications: Aircraft: The failure rate of an airplane is increased by 5 percent for each deployment. Repair jobs: Repair jobs entered after time 0 are randomly assigned to trading transactions. sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we address the problem of planning a dynamic workshop in the context of aircraft fleet management. Our proposed solution solves the dynamic problem as successive static planning problems over shorter periods of time. Multiple planning algorithms and different rescheduling policies are proposed to plan repair activities online with dynamic response to aircraft failures. The length of the planning horizon and frequency of rescheduling are the features that define our three policies. Calculation results show that an optimization approach using logical benders decomposition, planning over a longer horizon, incorporating the mean of known information about aircraft failures and adjusting the repair schedule as soon as new jobs enter the workshop results in higher mean coverage and is a reasonable approach to weigh against various uncertain scenarios.

sections.text: This research was partially supported by the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC) and the consortium members of the Centre for Maintenance Optimization & Reliability Engineering (C-MORE). Thanks to Nima Safaei and Dragan Banjevic for introducing the problem and the subsequent discussions, this paper is a combined and expanded version of a conference paper (Aramon Bajestani & Beck, 2011b) and a workshop paper (Aramon Bajestani & Beck, 2011a) that have already been published.

referenceMentions.context: The United States Air Force website outlines readiness as one of the vital elements to ensure the operational effectiveness in defense strategies (Schwartz, 2012).
In the other words, as in one of the standard repair models in the maintenance literature, repair is minimal (Wang, 2002).

The probability of failure detection in pre-flight checks is smaller than the post-flight checks because an aircraft is either just released from the repair shop or has already passed a previous post-flight check successfully (Safaei et al., 2011).

Repair shops have been mainly studied as a machine-repairman problem (Haque & Armstrong, 2007; Stecke, 1992) which has a set of workers and a set of machines that are subject to failures and therefore need repair.

Repair shops have been mainly studied as a machine-repairman problem (Haque & Armstrong, 2007; Stecke, 1992) which has a set of workers and a set of machines that are subject to failures and therefore need repair. Workers and machines respectively correspond to trades and aircraft, in our problem. As the number of workers is less than the number of machines, it is necessary to allocate the repair jobs to the workers with the goal of optimizing a given performance measure (e.g., the total expected machine downtime) over the long-term. Derman, Liberman, and Ross (1980) did the early work on solving the scheduling problem of a repair shop with a single repairman.
The process of modifying the previous schedule is called rescheduling (Vieira, Hermann, & Lin, 2003; Aytug et al., 2005; Bidot, Vidal, Laborie, & Beck, 2009).

Although we are not aware of using dynamic scheduling in a repair system, it has been successfully applied to a variety of scheduling problems including single machine (Ovacik & Uzsoy, 1994; O’Donovan et al., 1999; Cowling & Johansson, 2002), parallel machines (Vieira, Hermann, & Lin, 2000; Ovacik & Uzsoy, 1995), and job shop (Sabuncuoglu & Bayiz, 2000; Liu, Ong, & Ng, 2005; Vinod & Sridharan, 2011).

Starting with the early work of Wagner, Giglio, and Glaser (1964), this literature was extended through developing mathematical models and effective solution approaches for a variety of applications (Frost & Dechter, 1998; Haghani & Shafahi, 2002; Budai et al., 2006; Grigoriev, van de Klundert, & Spieksma, 2006).

Therefore, they typically result in a static dispatching-type repair policy similar to that found by Derman et al. (1980). However, in our problem, the waves have different plane requirements and the processing times and the resource requirements of the repair activities become known when they enter the repair shop.

The process of modifying the previous schedule is called rescheduling (Vieira, Hermann, & Lin, 2003; Aytug et al., 2005; Bidot, Vidal, Laborie, & Beck, 2009). How to solve static sub-problems and how to connect them using rescheduling strategies are the main aspects of the dynamic scheduling research. Although we are not aware of using dynamic scheduling in a repair system, it has been successfully applied to a variety of scheduling problems including single machine (Ovacik & Uzsoy, 1994; O’Donovan et al., 1999; Cowling & Johansson, 2002), parallel machines (Vieira, Hermann, & Lin, 2000; Ovacik & Uzsoy, 1995), and job shop (Sabuncuoglu & Bayiz, 2000; Liu, Ong, & Ng, 2005; Vinod & Sridharan, 2011). Other areas of literature with similarities to our static problem are the operational level maintenance scheduling problem, in general, and the flight and maintenance planning problem of military aircraft, specifically. The former literature addresses the problem of finding a schedule for given maintenance activities such that the sum of maintenance costs is minimized. The focus is on the operational level, determining the maintenance activities performed in each time period (Budai, Huisman, & Dekker, 2006). Starting with the early work of Wagner, Giglio, and Glaser (1964), this literature was extended through developing mathematical models and effective solution approaches for a variety of applications (Frost & Dechter, 1998; Haghani & Shafahi, 2002; Budai et al.

They later extended their work by using slightly different MIP model where the time-indexed approach is used to enforce the workforce availability constraint and they verified the validity of their model by a number of instances under different combinations of workforce sizes (Safaei et al., 2011).
Safaei et al. (2010) modeled the static problem addressed here as an operational level maintenance scheduling problem using MIP.
The classical Benders decomposition (Benders, 1962; Geoffrion & Graves, 1974) is a mathematical programming approach for solving large-scale mixed integer programming models.

Therefore, the inference duals (Hooker, 2005) of the SPs are solved rather than the linear duals to find the tightest bound on the global cost function from the original constraints and the current MP solution.
The former results in MP solutions which are likely to satisfy the SPs, and the latter rules out a large number of MP solutions in each iteration (Hooker, 2007).
Logic-based Benders decomposition has been shown to be effective in a wide range of problems including scheduling (Hooker, 2005, 2007; Beck, 2010), facility and vehicle
This problem is equivalent to a one dimensional knapsack problem with non-uniform profit which is shown to be NP-complete by reduction from the PARTITION problem (Pinedo, 2002).

The notation used for describing a problem in scheduling literature is α|β|γ where α represents the machine environment, β describes the processing characteristics and constraints in detail, and γ denotes the objective function (Pinedo, 2002).

The scheduling problems are usually defined as one or several instances of the constraints satisfaction problem (CSP) (Baptiste et al., 2001).

CP solves scheduling problems by applying three general tools of heuristic search, constraint propagation, and backtracking within a branch-and-bound search tree (Beck, 1999; Beck & Refalo, 2003).

Constraint propagation, one of the key principles contributing to the success of CP, is exploited by representing the problem as a conjunction of global constraints, each of which embeds efficient inference techniques that reduce the solution space within a branch-and-bound search tree (Baptiste et al., 2001).
The cumulative constraint ensures that the total amount of resource capacity used at any time never exceeds C (Hooker, 2005).

We therefore investigate a heuristic approach, inspired by the Apparent Tardiness Cost (ATC) heuristic, a composite dispatching rule that is typically applied to single machine scheduling problem with the sum of weighted tardiness objective (Pinedo, 2005).
It is worth mentioning that we have chosen three as the length of the scheduling horizon because three waves are usually scheduled daily based on the real data (Safaei et al., 2011).

Furthermore, our setting consists of more instances and results in problem instances which are one and a half times bigger than the examples used in the literature (Safaei et al., 2011) where the number of aircraft is 10, 15, or 20; the number of waves is 3 or 4; and the number of trades and aircraft types is equal to 3 and 2.
Though our problem instances are generated randomly, the setting of our experiment includes three numerical examples of Safaei et al. (2011) which are based on the real data.

The changes in the results compared to the previous work (Aramon Bajestani & Beck, 2011b) are due to improved scheduling models, different solvers, and different test problems. The scheduling algorithms are enhanced by using a smaller value for B, the resource capacity constraint is enforced in a shorter interval, i.e., [0, st|W |], and more efficient formulations for Constraints (5), (6), and (20) are used. The mean run-time of the MIP model given by Safaei et al. (2011) over eight scenarios with 10 aircraft and 3 waves is 294.
Bootstrap paired-t tests (Cohen, 1995) also indicate that there is no significant difference in mean run-time at p ≤ 0.

The P31 rescheduling policy is computationally more expensive than the other two policies, its run-time per one static sub-problem, however, is small compared to the length of scheduling horizon being usually one day in the real applications (Safaei et al., 2011).
The third approach is to use multi-stage dynamic programming for solving the dynamic repair shop problem (Iravani et al., 2007).

metadata.abstractText: We address a dynamic repair shop scheduling problem in the context of military aircraft fleet management where the goal is to maintain a full complement of aircraft over the longterm. A number of flights, each with a requirement for a specific number and type of aircraft, are already scheduled over a long horizon. We need to assign aircraft to flights and schedule repair activities while considering the flights requirements, repair capacity, and aircraft failures. The number of aircraft awaiting repair dynamically changes over time due to failures and it is therefore necessary to rebuild the repair schedule online. To solve the problem, we view the dynamic repair shop as successive static repair scheduling sub-problems over shorter time periods. We propose a complete approach based on the logic-based Benders decomposition to solve the static sub-problems, and design different rescheduling policies to schedule the dynamic repair shop. Computational experiments demonstrate that the Benders model is able to find and prove optimal solutions on average four times faster than a mixed integer programming model. The rescheduling approach having both aspects of scheduling over a longer horizon and quickly adjusting the schedule increases aircraft available in the long term by 10% compared to the approaches having either one of the aspects alone.
metadata.creator: TeX
